trans-unit.source: Feature engineering in the Cortana Analytics Process | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Feature engineering in the Cortana Analytics Process | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Explains the purposes of feature engineering and provides examples of its role in the data enhancement process of machine learning.
trans-unit.target: Explains the purposes of feature engineering and provides examples of its role in the data enhancement process of machine learning.

trans-unit.source: Feature engineering in the Cortana Analytics Process
trans-unit.target: Feature engineering in the Cortana Analytics Process

trans-unit.source: Feature engineering attempts to increase the predictive power of learning algorithms by creating features from raw data that help facilitate the learning process.
trans-unit.target: Feature engineering attempts to increase the predictive power of learning algorithms by creating features from raw data that help facilitate the learning process.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.INCLUDE [cap-create-features-data-selector](../../includes/cap-create-features-selector.md)] This **menu** links to topics that describe how to create features for data in various environments.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.INCLUDE [cap-create-features-data-selector](../../includes/cap-create-features-selector.md)] This **menu** links to topics that describe how to create features for data in various environments.

trans-unit.source: This task is a step in the [Cortana Analytics Process (CAP)](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/learning-paths/cortana-analytics-process/).
trans-unit.target: This task is a step in the [Cortana Analytics Process (CAP)](https://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/learning-paths/cortana-analytics-process/).

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: This topic explains the purposes of feature engineering and provides examples of its role in the data enhancement process of machine learning.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains the purposes of feature engineering and provides examples of its role in the data enhancement process of machine learning.

trans-unit.source: These examples are drawn from Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: These examples are drawn from Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: The engineering and selection of features is one part of the CAP process outlined in the [What is the Cortana Analytics Process?](machine-learning-data-science-the-cortana-analytics-process.md) Feature engineering and selection are parts of the **Develop features** step of the CAP.
trans-unit.target: The engineering and selection of features is one part of the CAP process outlined in the [What is the Cortana Analytics Process?](machine-learning-data-science-the-cortana-analytics-process.md) Feature engineering and selection are parts of the **Develop features** step of the CAP.

trans-unit.source: **feature engineering**: This process attempts to create additional relevant features from the existing raw features in the data, and to increase the predictive power of the learning algorithm.
trans-unit.target: **feature engineering**: This process attempts to create additional relevant features from the existing raw features in the data, and to increase the predictive power of the learning algorithm.

trans-unit.source: **feature selection**: This process selects the key subset of original data features in an attempt to reduce the dimensionality of the training problem.
trans-unit.target: **feature selection**: This process selects the key subset of original data features in an attempt to reduce the dimensionality of the training problem.

trans-unit.source: Normally **feature engineering** is applied first to generate additional features, and then the **feature selection** step is performed to eliminate irrelevant, redundant, or highly correlated features.
trans-unit.target: Normally **feature engineering** is applied first to generate additional features, and then the **feature selection** step is performed to eliminate irrelevant, redundant, or highly correlated features.

trans-unit.source: The training data used in machine learning can often be enhanced by extraction of features from the raw data collected.
trans-unit.target: The training data used in machine learning can often be enhanced by extraction of features from the raw data collected.

trans-unit.source: An example of an engineered feature in the context of learning how to classify the images of handwritten characters is creation of a bit density map constructed from the raw bit distribution data.
trans-unit.target: An example of an engineered feature in the context of learning how to classify the images of handwritten characters is creation of a bit density map constructed from the raw bit distribution data.

trans-unit.source: This map can help locate the edges of the characters more efficiently than simply using the raw distribution directly.
trans-unit.target: This map can help locate the edges of the characters more efficiently than simply using the raw distribution directly.

trans-unit.source: Creating Features from Your Data - Feature Engineering
trans-unit.target: Creating Features from Your Data - Feature Engineering

trans-unit.source: The training data consists of a matrix composed of examples (records or observations stored in rows), each of which has a set of features (variables or fields stored in columns).
trans-unit.target: The training data consists of a matrix composed of examples (records or observations stored in rows), each of which has a set of features (variables or fields stored in columns).

trans-unit.source: The features specified in the experimental design are expected to characterize the patterns in the data.
trans-unit.target: The features specified in the experimental design are expected to characterize the patterns in the data.

trans-unit.source: Although many of the raw data fields can be directly included in the selected feature set used to train a model, it is often the case that additional (engineered) features need to be constructed from the features in the raw data to generate an enhanced training dataset.
trans-unit.target: Although many of the raw data fields can be directly included in the selected feature set used to train a model, it is often the case that additional (engineered) features need to be constructed from the features in the raw data to generate an enhanced training dataset.

trans-unit.source: What kind of features should be created to enhance the dataset when training a model?
trans-unit.target: What kind of features should be created to enhance the dataset when training a model?

trans-unit.source: Engineered features that enhance the training provide information that better differentiates the patterns in the data.
trans-unit.target: Engineered features that enhance the training provide information that better differentiates the patterns in the data.

trans-unit.source: We expect the new features to provide additional information that is not clearly captured or easily apparent in the original or existing feature set.
trans-unit.target: We expect the new features to provide additional information that is not clearly captured or easily apparent in the original or existing feature set.

trans-unit.source: But this process is something of an art.
trans-unit.target: But this process is something of an art.

trans-unit.source: Sound and productive decisions often require some domain expertise.
trans-unit.target: Sound and productive decisions often require some domain expertise.

trans-unit.source: When starting with Azure Machine Learning, it is easiest to grasp this process concretely using samples provided in the Studio.
trans-unit.target: When starting with Azure Machine Learning, it is easiest to grasp this process concretely using samples provided in the Studio.

trans-unit.source: Two examples are presented here:
trans-unit.target: Two examples are presented here:

trans-unit.source: A regression example [Prediction of the number of bike rentals](../machine-learning-sample-prediction-of-number-of-bike-rentals.md) in a supervised experiment where the target values are known
trans-unit.target: A regression example [Prediction of the number of bike rentals](../machine-learning-sample-prediction-of-number-of-bike-rentals.md) in a supervised experiment where the target values are known

trans-unit.source: A text mining classification example using [Feature Hashing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/c9a82660-2d9c-411d-8122-4d9e0b3ce92a/)
trans-unit.target: A text mining classification example using [Feature Hashing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/c9a82660-2d9c-411d-8122-4d9e0b3ce92a/)

trans-unit.source: Example 1: Adding Temporal Features for Regression Model
trans-unit.target: Example 1: Adding Temporal Features for Regression Model

trans-unit.source: Let's use the experiment "Demand forecasting of bikes" in Azure Machine Learning Studio to demonstrate how to engineer features for a regression task.
trans-unit.target: Let's use the experiment "Demand forecasting of bikes" in Azure Machine Learning Studio to demonstrate how to engineer features for a regression task.

trans-unit.source: The objective of this experiment is to predict the demand for the bikes, that is, the number of bike rentals within a specific month/day/hour.
trans-unit.target: The objective of this experiment is to predict the demand for the bikes, that is, the number of bike rentals within a specific month/day/hour.

trans-unit.source: The dataset "Bike Rental UCI dataset" is used as the raw input data.
trans-unit.target: The dataset "Bike Rental UCI dataset" is used as the raw input data.

trans-unit.source: This dataset is based on real data from the Capital Bikeshare company that maintains a bike rental network in Washington DC in the United States.
trans-unit.target: This dataset is based on real data from the Capital Bikeshare company that maintains a bike rental network in Washington DC in the United States.

trans-unit.source: The dataset represents the number of bike rentals within a specific hour of a day in the years 2011 and year 2012 and contains 17379 rows and 17 columns.
trans-unit.target: The dataset represents the number of bike rentals within a specific hour of a day in the years 2011 and year 2012 and contains 17379 rows and 17 columns.

trans-unit.source: The raw feature set contains weather conditions (temperature/humidity/wind speed) and the type of the day (holiday/weekday).
trans-unit.target: The raw feature set contains weather conditions (temperature/humidity/wind speed) and the type of the day (holiday/weekday).

trans-unit.source: The field to predict is "cnt", a count which represents the bike rentals within a specific hour and which ranges ranges from 1 to 977.
trans-unit.target: The field to predict is "cnt", a count which represents the bike rentals within a specific hour and which ranges ranges from 1 to 977.

trans-unit.source: With the goal of constructing effective features in the training data, four regression models are built using the same algorithm but with four different training datasets.
trans-unit.target: With the goal of constructing effective features in the training data, four regression models are built using the same algorithm but with four different training datasets.

trans-unit.source: The four datasets represent the same raw input data, but with an increasing number of features set.
trans-unit.target: The four datasets represent the same raw input data, but with an increasing number of features set.

trans-unit.source: These features are grouped into four categories:
trans-unit.target: These features are grouped into four categories:

trans-unit.source: A = weather + holiday + weekday + weekend features for the predicted day
trans-unit.target: A = weather + holiday + weekday + weekend features for the predicted day

trans-unit.source: B = number of bikes that were rented in each of the previous 12 hours
trans-unit.target: B = number of bikes that were rented in each of the previous 12 hours

trans-unit.source: C = number of bikes that were rented in each of the previous 12 days at the same hour
trans-unit.target: C = number of bikes that were rented in each of the previous 12 days at the same hour

trans-unit.source: D = number of bikes that were rented in each of the previous 12 weeks at the same hour and the same day
trans-unit.target: D = number of bikes that were rented in each of the previous 12 weeks at the same hour and the same day

trans-unit.source: Besides feature set A, which already exist in the original raw data, the other three sets of features are created through the feature engineering process.
trans-unit.target: Besides feature set A, which already exist in the original raw data, the other three sets of features are created through the feature engineering process.

trans-unit.source: Feature set B captures very recent demand for the bikes.
trans-unit.target: Feature set B captures very recent demand for the bikes.

trans-unit.source: Feature set C captures the demand for bikes at a particular hour.
trans-unit.target: Feature set C captures the demand for bikes at a particular hour.

trans-unit.source: Feature set D captures demand for bikes at particular hour and particular day of the week.
trans-unit.target: Feature set D captures demand for bikes at particular hour and particular day of the week.

trans-unit.source: The four training datasets each includes feature set A, A+B, A+B+C, and A+B+C+D, respectively.
trans-unit.target: The four training datasets each includes feature set A, A+B, A+B+C, and A+B+C+D, respectively.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Machine Learning experiment, these four training datasets are formed via four branches from the pre-processed input dataset.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Machine Learning experiment, these four training datasets are formed via four branches from the pre-processed input dataset.

trans-unit.source: Except the left most branch, each of these branches contains an [Execute R Script](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5/) module, in which a set of derived features (feature set B, C, and D) are respectively constructed and appended to the imported dataset.
trans-unit.target: Except the left most branch, each of these branches contains an [Execute R Script](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/30806023-392b-42e0-94d6-6b775a6e0fd5/) module, in which a set of derived features (feature set B, C, and D) are respectively constructed and appended to the imported dataset.

trans-unit.source: The following figure demonstrates the R script used to create feature set B in the second left branch.
trans-unit.target: The following figure demonstrates the R script used to create feature set B in the second left branch.

trans-unit.source: ![create features](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/addFeature-Rscripts.png)
trans-unit.target: ![create features](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/addFeature-Rscripts.png)

trans-unit.source: The comparison of the performance results of the four models are summarized in the following table.
trans-unit.target: The comparison of the performance results of the four models are summarized in the following table.

trans-unit.source: The best results are shown by features A+B+C.
trans-unit.target: The best results are shown by features A+B+C.

trans-unit.source: Note that the error rate decreases when additional feature set are included in the training data.
trans-unit.target: Note that the error rate decreases when additional feature set are included in the training data.

trans-unit.source: It verifies our presumption that the feature set B, C provide additional relevant information for the regression task.
trans-unit.target: It verifies our presumption that the feature set B, C provide additional relevant information for the regression task.

trans-unit.source: But adding the D feature does not seem to provide any additional reduction in the error rate.
trans-unit.target: But adding the D feature does not seem to provide any additional reduction in the error rate.

trans-unit.source: ![result comparison](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/result1.png)
trans-unit.target: ![result comparison](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/result1.png)

trans-unit.source: Example 2: Creating Features in Text Mining
trans-unit.target: Example 2: Creating Features in Text Mining

trans-unit.source: Feature engineering is widely applied in tasks related to text mining, such as document classification and sentiment analysis.
trans-unit.target: Feature engineering is widely applied in tasks related to text mining, such as document classification and sentiment analysis.

trans-unit.source: For example, when we want to classify documents into several categories, a typical assumption is that the word/phrases included in one doc category are less likely to occur in another doc category.
trans-unit.target: For example, when we want to classify documents into several categories, a typical assumption is that the word/phrases included in one doc category are less likely to occur in another doc category.

trans-unit.source: In another words, the frequency of the words/phrases distribution is able to characterize different document categories.
trans-unit.target: In another words, the frequency of the words/phrases distribution is able to characterize different document categories.

trans-unit.source: In text mining applications, because individual pieces of text-contents usually serve as the input data, the feature engineering process is needed to create the features involving word/phrase frequencies.
trans-unit.target: In text mining applications, because individual pieces of text-contents usually serve as the input data, the feature engineering process is needed to create the features involving word/phrase frequencies.

trans-unit.source: To achieve this task, a technique called **feature hashing** is applied to efficiently turn arbitrary text features into indices.
trans-unit.target: To achieve this task, a technique called **feature hashing** is applied to efficiently turn arbitrary text features into indices.

trans-unit.source: Instead of associating each text feature (words/phrases) to a particular index, this method functions by applying a hash function to the features and using their hash values as indices directly.
trans-unit.target: Instead of associating each text feature (words/phrases) to a particular index, this method functions by applying a hash function to the features and using their hash values as indices directly.

trans-unit.source: In Azure Machine Learning, there is a [Feature Hashing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/c9a82660-2d9c-411d-8122-4d9e0b3ce92a/) module that creates these word/phrase features conveniently.
trans-unit.target: In Azure Machine Learning, there is a [Feature Hashing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/c9a82660-2d9c-411d-8122-4d9e0b3ce92a/) module that creates these word/phrase features conveniently.

trans-unit.source: Following figure shows an example of using this module.
trans-unit.target: Following figure shows an example of using this module.

trans-unit.source: The input dataset contains two columns: the book rating ranging from 1 to 5, and the actual review content.
trans-unit.target: The input dataset contains two columns: the book rating ranging from 1 to 5, and the actual review content.

trans-unit.source: The goal of this [Feature Hashing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/c9a82660-2d9c-411d-8122-4d9e0b3ce92a/) module is to retrieve a bunch of new features that show the occurrence frequency of the corresponding word(s)/phrase(s) within the particular book review.
trans-unit.target: The goal of this [Feature Hashing](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/c9a82660-2d9c-411d-8122-4d9e0b3ce92a/) module is to retrieve a bunch of new features that show the occurrence frequency of the corresponding word(s)/phrase(s) within the particular book review.

trans-unit.source: To use this module, we need to complete the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To use this module, we need to complete the following steps:

trans-unit.source: First, select the column that contains the input text ("Col2" in this example).
trans-unit.target: First, select the column that contains the input text ("Col2" in this example).

trans-unit.source: Second, set the "Hashing bitsize" to 8, which means 2^8=256 features will be created.
trans-unit.target: Second, set the "Hashing bitsize" to 8, which means 2^8=256 features will be created.

trans-unit.source: The word/phase in all the text will be hashed to 256 indices.
trans-unit.target: The word/phase in all the text will be hashed to 256 indices.

trans-unit.source: The parameter "Hashing bitsize" ranges from 1 to 31.
trans-unit.target: The parameter "Hashing bitsize" ranges from 1 to 31.

trans-unit.source: The word(s)/phrase(s) are less likely to be hashed into the same index if setting it to be a larger number.
trans-unit.target: The word(s)/phrase(s) are less likely to be hashed into the same index if setting it to be a larger number.

trans-unit.source: Third, set the parameter "N-grams" to 2.
trans-unit.target: Third, set the parameter "N-grams" to 2.

trans-unit.source: This gets the occurrence frequency of unigrams (a feature for every single word) and bigrams (a feature for every pair of adjacent words) from the input text.
trans-unit.target: This gets the occurrence frequency of unigrams (a feature for every single word) and bigrams (a feature for every pair of adjacent words) from the input text.

trans-unit.source: The parameter "N-grams" ranges from 0 to 10, which indicates the maximum number of sequential words to be included in a feature.
trans-unit.target: The parameter "N-grams" ranges from 0 to 10, which indicates the maximum number of sequential words to be included in a feature.

trans-unit.source: !["Feature Hashing" module](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/feature-Hashing1.png)
trans-unit.target: !["Feature Hashing" module](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/feature-Hashing1.png)

trans-unit.source: The following figure shows what the these new feature look like.
trans-unit.target: The following figure shows what the these new feature look like.

trans-unit.source: !["Feature Hashing" example](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/feature-Hashing2.png)
trans-unit.target: !["Feature Hashing" example](./media/machine-learning-data-science-create-features/feature-Hashing2.png)

trans-unit.source: Conclusion
trans-unit.target: Conclusion

trans-unit.source: Engineered and selected features increase the efficiency of the training process which attempts to extract the key information contained in the data.
trans-unit.target: Engineered and selected features increase the efficiency of the training process which attempts to extract the key information contained in the data.

trans-unit.source: They also improve the power of these models to classify the input data accurately and to predict outcomes of interest more robustly.
trans-unit.target: They also improve the power of these models to classify the input data accurately and to predict outcomes of interest more robustly.

trans-unit.source: Feature engineering and selection can also combine to make the learning more computationally tractable.
trans-unit.target: Feature engineering and selection can also combine to make the learning more computationally tractable.

trans-unit.source: It does so by enhancing and then reducing the number of features needed to calibrate or train a model.
trans-unit.target: It does so by enhancing and then reducing the number of features needed to calibrate or train a model.

trans-unit.source: Mathematically speaking, the features selected to train the model are a minimal set of independent variables that explain the patterns in the data and then predict outcomes successfully.
trans-unit.target: Mathematically speaking, the features selected to train the model are a minimal set of independent variables that explain the patterns in the data and then predict outcomes successfully.

trans-unit.source: Note that it is not always necessarily to perform feature engineering or feature selection.
trans-unit.target: Note that it is not always necessarily to perform feature engineering or feature selection.

trans-unit.source: Whether it is needed or not depends on the data we have or collect, the algorithm we pick, and the objective of the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Whether it is needed or not depends on the data we have or collect, the algorithm we pick, and the objective of the experiment.
